turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in number 1427, McDaniel v. Paty.
Mr. LeClercq, I think you may proceed.

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
The appellant in this case is Paul McDaniel, a minister from Chattanooga, Tennessee.

He declared as a candidate and properly filed as a candidate for delegate to the 1977 Tennessee constitutional convention at which time he was sued by one of his opponents to have his name stricken from the ballot because he was a Minister of the Gospel and a provision of the present Tennessee constitution Article 9 provides that no priest or minister of the Gospel may serve in legislative office in Tennessee and the call to the Tennessee constitutional convention of 1977, picked up that qualification for persons who were to serve as delegates to the constitutional convention.
The matter was heard in the Chancery Court in Hamilton County and the chancellor enjoined the requirement as being in violation of the free exercise of religion.

An appeal was taken to the Tennessee Supreme Court which remanded for not having given notice to the Attorney General, the case was then heard in the Chancery Court of Hamilton County with the Attorney General appearing and the chancellor again enjoined the provision on Establishment Clause grounds.
During the period when an appeal was taken to the Tennessee Supreme Court by the State and Ms. Paty, the election was held and Reverend McDaniel won handily.
He came with a few votes of having more than the other three candidates combined.
The Tennessee Supreme Court heard this case and decided that Reverend McDaniel could not serve because of the provision of the Tennessee constitution and upheld the exclusion on separation grounds.

Counsel then sought a stay from Mr. Justice Stewart which was denied with suggestion that application be made to the Tennessee Supreme Court which was then done and the Tennessee Supreme Court granted a stay until June 20, 1977, at which time the Tennessee Supreme Court denied a second request for a stay and Mr. Justice Stewart then granted appellantâ€™s request for a stay.
The constitutional convention began August 01, 1977 and Reverend McDaniel has been sitting as a delegate to that convention under the stay granted by Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is it still on session, the constitutional --?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: The constitutional convention is still on session.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Any anticipation or anything you tell from the record about when they expected it end?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: It is very difficult to predict when legislative groups in Tennessee will end.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Or anywhere else?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: This will happen counsel, if upon the election or upon filing as a candidate under the Tennessee law, the ordained minister renounced his ordination and resigned, would that clear him with the disability or do we not know?
Is there --

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Clearly, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He might be tainted for life?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: You know, that issue that, we face that issue in the brief, on the waiving of this question and this was a very much question in the England, can one renounce his ministry, can one be defrocked and then run for office.
It is by no means clear on the face of the Tennessee, a disqualifying provision whether that could be done.
Now, this case, the issues in this case involve several provisions of a constitution.
This is a voting rights case.
It involves a right to be a candidate for a public office which this Court has vindicated in the past.
It involves voting rights as well since the right to vote for priest or ministers of the Gospel is an important right.

We face the same question in this case that was faced by the Court some years back when it addressed the question of whether the persons in the military could be fenced out from candidacy or from exercise of their voting rights.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In what cases have we vindicated what you describe the right to be a candidate?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Its my opinion Mr. Justice Rehnquist, that this was done in Bullock and in Lubin v. Panish and in American Party of Texas v. White.

It seems to me that one can say that the rights of candidates, qua candidates were vindicated in these cases although I do not think it makes a great deal of difference even if the Court should choose to vindicate these rights as voting rights.
We also have at stake here Free Exercise Rights because Reverend McDaniel has chosen to exercise his rights as a Minister of the Gospel.

He has been penalized in his voting rights so you have a situation where the appellant is put in the -- to the absence of choice of either choosing between his voting rights which this Court has declared are fundamental, or his Free Exercise Rights which this Court has declared are fundamental.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: His voting rights being his right to vote for himself?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Yes, yes or for any other minister since this has been certified as a class action by the chancellor of the Hamilton County Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: One may be -- both may be fundamental, but only one is a constitutionally protected right, is that not correct?
You read the case Minor v. Happerstett, you will find it stated there by the Court unanimously as I remember that there is no constitutional right to vote?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, we look --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because that case, it may necessary the amendment of our constitution to allow woman to vote, that was an equal protection case.
Court said the Equal Protection Clause gave no such right?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: We look upon the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whereas the First Amendment protects and creates freedoms and rights to that?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Yes, but we think the voting rights cases of this Court are sufficient to -- as well to give -- to seek a vote.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Who was in this class?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: All ministers who shall be candidates for office of delegate to the constitutional -- to there is a future constitutional conventions and all candidates for legislative office.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, how can that be a class?
I thought a class was a large number of people?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, we think there may be a number of other ministers who --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then one?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Marshall, it is my understanding that there are several other ministers who are serving at this time as delegates to the Tennessee constitutional convention.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that in this case?
Was that -- is that in place in this case, a propaganda?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: We did not know at the time that this class was certified that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But I thought the class had been numbers that there was too many to name.
I am not using exact language, but I think that is what the language is?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: The state class action requirement is patterned upon Rule 23.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Why does in the class include every ordained minister in the State of Tennessee, whether or not he has a present intention of running for anything?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, that is point well taken Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It is an inhibition that whole --

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: That has an inhibition --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Supreme Court is in inhibition now trusting on every ordained minister in the state, is it right?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I think that the -- it -- that really would not matter very much; however, because if the class for relief or afforded as appellants are, any minister who ever wanted to seek legislative office in Tennessee would be allowed to do so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But it is very important to us now for our purposes whether it is hyper class action or whether it is only one man?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I think it is important for this reason.

If we strike down Chapter 848 of the Tennessee Public Acts of 1976, a dealing with the call to this convention then we only deal with this particular call and it means that next year should some minister in Tennessee choose to be a candidate for legislative office that he could be excluded under this provision and it would entail the great expense that has been entailed in this or any other case that comes to this Court, to afford relief and we may not have before to at this event then which occurred here.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, this Court always if it -- suppose if we disagree with the judgment of the Supreme Court of Tennessee our mandate as always vacated and reversed for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.

We would not tell as I understand our practice, the Supreme Court of Tennessee what the form of mandate to send down to the Chancery Court in Hamilton County, so long as it was not inconsistent with our opinion?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, the only problem that I could see coming from that is that the Supreme Court of Tennessee limited the cross appeal taken by appellant from the chancellorâ€™s ruling to this particular case and this particular statute and they relied on I believe the Storey (ph) case in Tennessee which in our brief counsel has alleged is an Epperson.
The -- it is simply a quest of whether this Court is willing to resolve this question in Tennessee.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You have a precedent in any event.
If we said -- if we simply decided it on a narrowest of grounds which --

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: That is quite true sir, but it is also true that chancellors and circuit judges at the local level in Tennessee may view precedents in very different lights and if this Court granted relief only as to the call for the 1976 -- 1977 convention, it is possible that some local judge may try to distinguish that away, and deny relief to some ministerial candidate for a legislative office then the election would be held and ultimately even though the state appellate court may choose to grant relief it would be faced with a very disruptive possibility of having to invalidate an election, call an election again.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, you would have all the same remedies that were available to you in this case, would you not?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: You know, we are very lucky that we had a good chancellor at the local level who afforded relief and allowed our candidate to run.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I am stating of the state processes -

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Got a good circuit justice?[Laughter]

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Very fine.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But if the chancellor is still there, so the justice is still here?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Yeah, but we do not have him in every county in Tennessee Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if you want us to draw a decree that stop every judicial officer in the State of Tennessee from doing wrong, forget about it ?[Laughter]

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: We do not expect that, but we would like -- we do think that we are entitled to a decree that would prevent the state of Tennessee from ever disqualifying for candidacy for a public office.
Any person because of his being a priest or a Minister of the Gospel.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. LeClercq could I ask you a question about your theory on the merits.

Supposing Tennessee had a law that said that no one, simply decide they want to have a fresh look at the whole governmental structure and they would like to exclude from those participating in the constitutional convention anyone presently serving in the state legislature or in the state executive department, so they have just excluded all senior government officials, would that be permissible?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: In my opinion it certainly would.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But why would they not be forced to make the same kind of absence of choice between serving in the legislature or serving in the constitutional convention?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Because that is -- that is a matter of choosing between two secular offices and the state can decide that a man ought to spend all of his time on one secular office and not split his responsibilities, but the state under the First Amendment, under the Establishment Clause and under the Free Exercise Clause, state has no business interfering in what a person does one way or the other.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What if their theory is that well, these people now in public office are unduly influential on the deliberations of the new body and they might think ministers are unduly persuasive, they can use certain kinds of arguments that some of the rest of us cannot use and so we better keep them out of these debates?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, as to the influence of ministers, I do not think that it would be permissible to exclude presidents of cooperations and many of them exert substantial influence, presidents of universities, many of them exert substantial influence and I would say that it would certainly deny ministers as a clientâ€™s equal protection to treat them differently from other persons who have equal or greater amounts of influence.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Okay, exclude all college presidents were valid what is the Section of a constitution?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I think it would violate Equal Protection Clause because it would be treating people who are similarly situated differently.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Suppose it excluded all lawyers?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, we have a reference to that in the brief, and in that column it was called the black learning Parliament.
I think that a case could be made for excluding lawyers which could not be made for excluding ministers.
I would hate to see that done.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But why?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Because it would be singling out an occupational class for invidious treatment without any reference to the capacity of that group to serve.

Many of the lawyers who serve in legislatures, serve very honorably and with distinction and in 49 other states in the union, ministers are permitted to serve in the legislature and it is only because of anachronism that goes back to the Tennessee constitution of 1796.(Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you know if anybody who could be excluded?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, I answered Mr. Justice Stevenâ€™s question.
I think the state could certainly exclude justices of its court from serving in the legislature or any officer in government.
There is no problem with the validity of the PATCH (ph) Act to similar state laws.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what about all ministers?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, I think that was --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, they are -- they are chaplains in every penitentiary in North Carolina, are they not?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, but whereas a minister --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Are they?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I do not know.
Ministers --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Assuming that they are chaplains in the state penitentiaries on the payroll of the state, they exclude?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I think the state might exclude any state officer because --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Even if he happens to be a minister?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: How it say even if he happens to be a minister.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: On your theory he would not be singled out as a a minister, but as a state employee?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: As a state employee.
Yes, that would be a rationale classification, but this classification is not rationale and it singles out persons for invidious treatment because of their --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What do you think the First Amendment, your --?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I think it is both sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It is both.

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: And I -- that we submit this as a -- this that the -- of course the Free Exercise and Establishment Clauses have been incorporated or absorbed by the Fourteenth and in that sense it is both the First and the Fourteenth Amendment case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And equal protection?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Yes, it is an equal protection case in that we are contending that the state has denied the voting rights and rights of political candidacy to ministers and I cited earlier the cases on which we rely on voting.
I also think its a due process case on vagueness grounds.
Who is there to determine, who is a minister or priest; within the meaning of this Tennessee statute.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, ultimately I suppose your state Supreme Court would -- might be called upon to do it?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: It is a very difficult task and it invites the very type of entanglement problems that this Court has tried to avoid, determining who is a minister --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How many -- how many denominations make all of them members, adherence ministers of that church.
There are several I believe?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Yes, there are --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I recall in your brief you numbered all of them or not, undertook to?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: No, we -- I am sure that our list was not, was not exhaustive, but it was suggestive of the -- of a number of denominations which the Mormons for example require that each member of the faith engage in a ministry of several years, when they perform religious functions.

The -- a number of fundamentalist religions hire working preachers who are involved in the community and they have own job, they support themselves with a regular job, but they preach on Sunday, would such a person be disqualifying under the Tennessee Act.
We think that the vagueness problems on due process grounds with the statute are very substantial.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But there is vagueness as to your client to Mr. LeClercq (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: No vagueness absolutely not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: With respect to the 1641 legislation in England, your very interesting brief describe the historical conditions then and how important the clergy was in England at that time.
If we thought that the clergy was equally important in Tennessee when this statute was passed, would you say that statute was unrational?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: There is a vital distinction between the situation in England in 1641 and the situation in Tennessee in 1796 in that the church was established in England and the danger in England was that the commons which controlled the appropriation of funds, if dominated by Anglican priests, would vogue the state church great sums of money.

Since we have no established church in Tennessee and never have had an established church, I think the argument would be an opposite, but I think you know that 1641 Act, with frames like that the church needs few in its.
A couple other points; the constitution, the body of the constitution itself ride in the same Section with the Supremacy Clause, provides that there shall be no religious test for office.

Now, there is some question as to whether that applies to state offices, or whether it applies only to federal offices, but it seems to me, coming where it does in the constitution, with the Supremacy Clause, that that clause of a constitution also affords a basis for overturning this constitution, this requirement.

Now, of course the support in the decisions of this Court are not as great for that argument as it is for the arguments that I have been discussing, but I do think that that is a a respectable argument.

It has been made, I believe Mr. Justice Black a number of years back uses this either a basis of a concurring or a dissenting opinion and I think a respectable argument can be made looking back to Farrand Records of the Federal Convention and even if the Court were to decide that, that clause did not apply in full force at the time it was adopted, it would be permissible for that guarantee as being a fundamental guarantee to be received through the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I ask one other historical question Mr. LeClercq?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Your brief pointed out that that Thomas Jefferson once might have disagreed with your argument here and that he later changed his mind --

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Which is a credit and strength.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you suppose anything, any provision that could have commended itself to justice, to Thomas Jefferson even for a few years and even temporarily it could be so irrational, we have to strike it down?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Well, Thomas in this view commended itself to Thomas Jefferson only at a time prior to the enactment of the first amendment and I think that explains Mr. Jeffersonâ€™s position.

I think historically, one can justify these clauses in the state constitutions of 1776 because at the time the church in this county had not been disestablished and as Your Honor knows the church was not disestablished I think in Massachusetts until 1830 or 1831, so there was a very great fear of an established church, but the First Amendment with its establishment clause put those fears to rest and it is interesting that this Tennessee provision with 1796, this is only four years after the First Amendment or five years, the -- so it is, this amendment is -- this, this Tennessee provision is really contemporaneous with the First Amendment and it policy wise, it looks back to a time before the First Amendment.

Now, whether or not the framers of this amendment were anti-clerical, there were some anti-clerical forces in Tennessee at that time or whether they were trying to give a preference for religion, in either case the clause would fall on establishment clause grounds.
Your Honor, if I may, if there are no further questions, I would like to save the remaining time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Herrell.

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
Under the constitution that we live under in this country, we have certain fundamental rights which are gained to us or guaranteed to us by the constitution and the amendments.
These are fundamental, so fundamental that they cannot be taken away from this.
However, we also have other rights that we have enjoy in this country that can be somewhat preemptive because they are not absolutely guaranteed by our constitution.
The case we have for consideration here today involves these two questions, these two principles which I want to explore.
These cover all the issues, I believe that have been made in this case, the issue of Free Exercise of Religion, the Establishment Clause, the Equal Protection Clause and the Due Process Clause.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They are all expressed provisions which is --

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Of a transition or they not?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes sir, but this -- my purpose here that I want to attempt to distinguish this case as it has been decided by this Court citing certain applications of a personâ€™s right and they first categorically have cases where they are absolute that is the right pertaining to a belief.
This cannot be changed by our concept of a constitution.
This Court would not do so.
However, there are certain practices which cannot be limited I think by the application of activities of a person who wants to enjoy his rights under a constitution.
For instance, this Court has said in the Castle case, a case is not taken to interpret the question of a right or a belief.
This Court said properly that that could not be compelled.
Likewise the case has said, therefore, you have a question involving sanctions, as it was indicated in the Schempp case.
That cannot be condoned.

Now, as this Court has said in Cantwell the free actively to have to act is not absolute, it comes in this later category and cannot be subject to certain limitations where there are proper basis for it.
For instance, in the Sherbert case, this Court said that was an indirect burden by inhabit to Free Exercise Right where there is a compelling state interest.
In the Braunfeld case, the Court has said that a state may limit a personâ€™s practice.
You know it may cause some inconvenience in time and in Walz case, a valid secular objective is an appropriate subject of legislation.
We submit that that is what we have for consideration before us at this time.

Now, as to the Establishment Clause, I do not think that at least be said there is any question, but what the purpose of this clause is to keep the state from establishing any form of religion, any requirement for a particular religi.
We submit that there has been no establishment created by the virtue of the Acts in question here, and again, under Schempp, a secular purpose is a valid basis for a legislative purpose.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What is the valid secular objective here?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: That is the separation of church and state, that I want to get into.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that is the only?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But then this brings us to attention a potential conflict between the Establishment Clause and the Free Exercise Clause, does it not?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: That is correct and that is the point that I want to explore now on test that this Court has used in interpreting this kind of -- kinds of -- cases of this kind.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Attorney General when was this provision first enacted?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: It was enacted in original constitution of Tennessee in 1796, but it was carried over basically from the constitution of North Carolina.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Has it been reconsidered?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Has it ever been litigated?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you think it is time?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Well, it is before the Court now.
There are three tests that this Court can consider as been recognized previously as a basis for a test to consider the application of this test.

The rationale basis test, that is the minimum test and to the other extreme there is a compelling state interest test, which is on not relevant to get into now and we submit to the Court that the proper test for this Court as laid down in Bullock is the strict scrutiny test.
What basis that does a state have?
Is it sufficient?
The state submits that it is a sufficient basis.
Under this principle, the test the system must be closed to scrutinized and found to be reasonable and necessary for the carrying out of a legitimate state purpose.
We submit that this is a legitimate state purpose, that is the separation of church and state.

It is recognized likewise that state cannot be arbitrary in attempting to accomplish its goals, but we submit there is no arbitrary action in this case and a criterion for different treatments must bear some relevance to the object, the object being the separation of church and state which is at issue here.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you happen to know whether we have had any Presidents except one who was an ordained minister?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I do not.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: President Wilson was a Presbyterian minister of course, no other --

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Recall that to our attention (Inaudible), I am not aware of any other though.
Now we move onto other questions that have been raised in this case, that is a question of equal protection.
As this Court has said in Walker there is no fundamental right or suspect case to consider in this case.
All ministers are treated and like in similar manner.
What applies to one, would apply to all.
As our Court said in the case that it calls, I mean, it covers priests of all denominations and their counterparts in other religions.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought your opponent was complained not so much about the distinctions between priests and ministers as distinctions -- as the distinction between the clergy and the rest of the population?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: But if we consider the stateâ€™s basis, we think that there is a sufficient basis to put them in a category to themselves that is for the separation of church and state.
I would like to suggest to the Court to what it has found that there is no fundamental right to hold off and --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Attorney General, it was in the state said that nobody who goes to church every week shall serve in the state legislature, a regular church goers are two religions have a complete separation?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: I think that will violate one of their religious Tennessee where they had a right to worship or their fundamental belief --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I believe that nothing would prevent them from pertaining to go to church, it is just could not be in the state legislature that is all?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Well, I think that that would be in the same category that we have before us.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You say that would be equally valid or invalid like this statute?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes, sir.
This Court has likewise said in Turner that there is no fundamental right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You are not going so for as to approve the statute that says thereby believes in God, cannot (Inaudible) would you?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: No, sir.
That involves their fundamental belief.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But where this is?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you said they -- do I understand you to say you could say that as long as you serve in the legislature, you may not go to church more than once a month?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Well, in first place --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what -- that sounds to me like what you said, at least you may not go to church every week?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Well, if you assume that premise I think that would be true yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know, but that is what I thought is that what you have answered to Mr. Justice Stevens?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes, sir it is.

This Court too has recently said in the Williams case that there is no basis for a claim that fundamental as a political right for association, no discriminations against a group and in connection with that I would like to point out what we feel the Court defect that this case was not brought as a class action to the attention of this Court.
There is no assignment made on that.
The Tennessee Supreme Court said that there was not a class action involved in this.
Now, this Court has had before it considerations of another cases, questions of whether religious organizations or rather all members of the organization entitled to the exceptions.

Again, I want to call the attention to the fact that our Court has said that the ministers cover all beliefs that is those who would lead their people, tech them, or there would be other Christian religion or of any other religion, so from this I do not believe it can be said that you have a question of vagueness as to who is a minister.
This Court under Selective Service Acts have had questions about ministers.

I do not need to call that to your attention, such case involving Dickinson, and as a group, ministers have been given special attention or special privileges namely under the Selective Service Act for instance.
They are exempt from service under the Selective Service Acts.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And I assume they also give (Inaudible) all of these meetings that you are talking about from which they are excluded?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes, sir and likewise we have certain benefits for members of the clergy, such as benefits from our federal income tax provisions not including all of their income.

A question has been raised here as to whether there are ministers in the Tennessee general assembly, all of the prisons and the â€“ for instance in the prisons in the state, all prisons in the state of Tennessee have ministers to serving to the needs of the inmates.
That I think they have several.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, are they paid by the state, provided by the state?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that what you are telling us?
There are some states where they permit ministers from the outside, but not necessarily making them employees of the state, I wanted to be sure that which Tennessee has?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: So, by way of summary and conclusions here I want to state again that there is no attempt made to regulate or control the belief of anyone in the Tennessee relative to what they can believe so as to exclude them from the membership as a minister.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Attorney General I just before you finish your opponent made some, places an emphasis on whether or not there was an established church in jurisdiction which had this sort of provision?
Does Tennessee have an established church at the very beginning of its statehood?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: To my knowledge there has not been an established church in the state of Tennessee.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And how about this law state of Franklin that forgets it is intermediate between North Carolina and Tennessee.
Was that any established Church in that state as far as you know?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Not to my knowledge and in the law State of Franklin was an initial attempt to establish a state in the State of Tennessee in the eastern part.

That particular state for one reason or another gave up its charter and reverted back as a part of North Carolina and then a later attempt was made to establish the State of Tennessee which was then except --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Franklin went back in the North Carolina I thought was part of Eastern Tennessee?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In your submission I take it that those denominations which make all of the members ministers of that church, would exclude all the members?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes, sir.
We have to stand and say that ministers if they are those as to find in the Tennessee case, which on attack to me to, I mean the on attack to minister to the needs of their congregations.
To that extent they would be included.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, under the Tennessee definition must there be an identifiable congregation in order to make its leader a minister?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: I do not think so unless -- if as long as he would be in that category or he would on attack to lead some of the people.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How could he get out from under being turned a minister under Tennessee law?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: That could bring a very difficult decision that had to be made --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Difficult or impossible?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Well, I think you might even say impossible to the extent that once a man is qualified as minister and has those believes that he could be said to continue those in his thoughts subconsciously.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And be excluded?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: And be excluded yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: By trying to taking --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I assume that if he says that I am no longer Minister of the Gospel, I am adient, that would not happen?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Well, if he professes to be Methodist and does not adhere to this religion that might be a little different category.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, he might make it if he becomes an adient?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You cannot put the thread back on a tire by running the car in reverse?

turn.speaker: kenneth_r_herrell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth R. Herrell
turn.text: That is what I am trying to say, yes sir.
Again, I want to summarize this very briefly to say that there is no attempt made to regulate the belief by this Act.

There is no attempt made to regulate a practice of a religion by the Act that is in question and there is no denial of the appellantâ€™s rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and all ministers and their counterparts, all religions are excluded on provisions of Article IX Section 1 of the Tennessee Constitution.
There is no fundamental right over public office.
If the Court has no further questions, I have to submit.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Do you not have anything further Mr. LeClercq?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Briefly.

The separation of church and state argument which has been made by the Attorney General of Tennessee is a state doctrine and it is our position that this runs a foul of the federal separation of church and state doctrine.

The question of whether this case is brought as a class action to this Court, appellantâ€™s position on that issue is that it was properly certified as a class action by the Chancery and that the authority on which the Tennessee Court relied to deny the cross appeal of appellant was in opposite --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The federal question is raised by that?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: It is a question of whether or not this issue must be addressed again in some other litigation after this case has been decided.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What federal right were you denied by the Supreme Court of Tennessee's ruling on that aspect of the case?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: The rights, person similarly situated to Reverend McDaniel to assert their federally protected rights to seek legislative office in the --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where do we find that enunciated in the constitution or in the cases?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: It would be in the voting rights, it would be in the same Free Exercise and Establishment Rights that are being asserted here.
It is also a question of economics.

It is a question of whether or not counsel -- whether that there is a likelihood of this Courtâ€™s decision leaving open the way for counsel to have to come back up and do this sort of thing again on candidacy for legislative office.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Are you against that or for that?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I would be very much in favor of saving the money.

Indeed that speaking of money, this is a 1983 action for which if appellant prevails there is a right to Attorney fees also under the Voting Right Section of the Voting Rights Act of 1975, there is a provision for an award of Attorney fees to prevailing counsel in Voting Rights litigations or it would seem to me that it would even be in the interest of the State of Tennessee to have the thing decided once and for all unless they want to pay counsel to do the same thing that has already been done.

The matter of ministers having special privileges being excluded from the service, ready answer to that which we provided in our brief, is that this is to encourage the Free Exercise Rights of those who have been removed from their churches by being drafted or otherwise going into the army.
The tax rights, similarly this is to advance Free Exercise Rights, the tax advantages which are afforded to ministers.
The difference between the tax advantages and the service provisions relating to ministers involved in this case, is it here there is a penalty against ministers and those cases involve preferences.

So one other point the -- the it -- although it is not commanded a majority view on this Court, it is the case that the appellant is a black minister and in the amended complaint it was alleged that the affect of this provision is to disproportionately exclude a black leadership from candidacy for a public office because this Court can take notice of that fact --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You do not have any Negro politicians in Tennessee who are not ministers?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: We got a lot of them, but what we are saying is that the leadership in the black community traditionally has been overrepresented in the ministry and even though this Court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You are making statements that you cannot back up and I do not think you should make it unless you got the facts to back them up, would you agree?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I believe that the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You are talking about the leadership of Negroes in Tennessee, now cite your authority for that statement?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Your Honor, my time is up, but I would write to respond to --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You may respond I took your response to mean that of the professions, Negroes are proportionately have a higher representation in the clergy than in other professions?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: In law or in medicine?
Black lawyers or black doctors could run for office.
Black ministers cannot and since leadership --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And how many white ministers are in the Mormon Church?
Yeah, because every member is --

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: I think this -- this case trans -- certainly transcends racial rounds because it affects white ministers as well as blacks.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But does it really have anything to do with race at all?
Suppose we had not known because I did not that this man was a Negro, white, Chinese or whatever.
Does it make any difference to the fundamental issues that you are presenting here?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: No, its just an additional reason.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, then we continue to concern ourselves with the case?

turn.speaker: frederic_s_leclercq
turn.label: Mr. Frederic S. Leclercq
turn.text: Alright sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentleman.
The case is submitted.
